<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 418, 228, 434]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 435, 880, 604]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- You should use a calculator where appropriate.- You must show all necessary working clearly; no marks will be given for unsupported answers from a calculator.- Give non-exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place for angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 634, 219, 649]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 650, 728, 682]]<|/det|>
INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 80.- The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[415, 79, 615, 97]]<|/det|>
Mathematical Formulae  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[453, 139, 576, 159]]<|/det|>
## 1. ALGEBRA  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 171, 255, 191]]<|/det|>
Quadratic Equation  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[131, 201, 400, 220]]<|/det|>
For the equation \(ax^{2} + bx + c = 0\)  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[432, 220, 596, 255]]<|/det|>
\[x = \frac{-b\pm\sqrt{b^{2} - 4ac}}{2a}\]  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 278, 243, 295]]<|/det|>
Binomial Theorem  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[260, 297, 767, 338]]<|/det|>
\[(a + b)^{n} = a^{n} + \binom{n}{1} a^{n - 1}b + \binom{n}{2} a^{n - 2}b^{2} + \ldots +\binom{n}{r} a^{n - r}b^{r} + \ldots +b^{n}\]  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[131, 351, 514, 390]]<|/det|>
where \(n\) is a positive integer and \(\binom{n}{r} = \frac{n!}{(n - r)!r!}\)  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 415, 400, 435]]<|/det|>
Arithmetic series \(u_{n} = a + (n - 1)d\)  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[260, 440, 549, 471]]<|/det|>
\[S_{n} = \frac{1}{2} n(a + l) = \frac{1}{2} n\left\{2a + (n - 1)d\right\}\]  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 494, 351, 513]]<|/det|>
Geometric series \(u_{n} = a r^{n - 1}\)  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[260, 515, 445, 580]]<|/det|>
\[S_{n} = \frac{a(1 - r^{n})}{1 - r} (r\neq 1)\] \[S_{\infty} = \frac{a}{1 - r} (|r|< 1)\]  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[415, 617, 609, 636]]<|/det|>
## 2. TRIGONOMETRY  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 650, 171, 667]]<|/det|>
Identities  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[430, 677, 598, 730]]<|/det|>
\[\sin^{2}A + \cos^{2}A = 1\] \[\sec^{2}A = 1 + \tan^{2}A\] \[\csc^{2}A = 1 + \cot^{2}A\]  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 772, 256, 790]]<|/det|>
Formulae for \(\Delta ABC\)  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[418, 797, 609, 833]]<|/det|>
\[\frac{a}{\sin A} = \frac{b}{\sin B} = \frac{c}{\sin C}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[418, 833, 609, 853]]<|/det|>
\[a^{2} = b^{2} + c^{2} - 2bc\cos A\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[455, 860, 571, 890]]<|/det|>
\[\Delta = \frac{1}{2} bc\sin A\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 92, 94, 111]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 79, 920, 129]]<|/det|>
Write \(\frac{\left(pqr\right)^{-2}r^{\frac{1}{3}}}{\left(p^{2}r\right)^{-1}q^{3}}\) in the form \(p^{a}q^{b}r^{c}\), where \(a, b\) and \(c\) are constants.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 92, 920, 111]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 75, 97, 94]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 75, 146, 94]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 75, 920, 97]]<|/det|>
On the axes, sketch the graph of \(y = \left|4 - 3x\right|\), stating the intercepts with the coordinate axes.[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 460, 146, 479]]<|/det|>

Solve the inequality \(\left|4 - 3x\right| \geqslant 7\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 460, 920, 479]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 94, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 301, 920, 337]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows the quadrilateral \(OABC\) such that \(\overrightarrow{OA} = \mathbf{a}\), \(\overrightarrow{OB} = \mathbf{b}\) and \(\overrightarrow{OC} = \mathbf{c}\). The lines \(OB\) and \(AC\) intersect at the point \(P\), such that \(AP:PC = 3:2\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 348, 144, 368]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 348, 384, 368]]<|/det|>
Find \(\overrightarrow{OP}\) in terms of \(\mathbf{a}\) and \(\mathbf{c}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 350, 920, 368]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 630, 146, 648]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 630, 598, 648]]<|/det|>
Given also that \(OP:PB = 2:3\), show that \(2\mathbf{b} = 3\mathbf{c} + 2\mathbf{a}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 630, 920, 648]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 85, 94, 104]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 75, 920, 121]]<|/det|>
A curve is such that \(\frac{\mathrm{d}^{2}y}{\mathrm{d}x^{2}} = (3x + 2)^{-\frac{1}{3}}\). The curve has gradient 4 at the point (2, 6.2). Find the equation of the curve.  [6]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 96, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>6</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 71, 586, 92]]<|/det|>
**DO NOT USE A CALCULATOR IN THIS QUESTION.**

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 102, 124, 121]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[126, 101, 524, 122]]<|/det|>
curve has equation \(y = \left(3 + \sqrt{5}\right)x^{2} - 8\sqrt{5} x + 60.\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 133, 144, 152]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 131, 920, 168]]<|/det|>
Find the \(x\)-coordinate of the stationary point on the curve, giving your answer in the form \(a + b\sqrt{5}\), where \(a\) and \(b\) are integers.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 151, 920, 168]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 75, 146, 92]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 73, 920, 109]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 87, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 504, 922, 540]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 918, 112]]<|/det|>

<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 920, 107]]<|/det|>
The first three terms of an arithmetic progression are \(- 4, 8, 20\). Find the smallest number of terms for which the sum of this arithmetic progression is greater than 2000.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 87, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 146, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 71, 920, 106]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 117, 180, 135]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 117, 344, 135]]<|/det|>
this common ratio,

<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 456, 920, 494]]<|/det|>
Explain why the geometric progression \(1, \sin \theta, \sin^2 \theta, \ldots\) for \(-\frac{\pi}{2} < \theta < \frac{\pi}{2}\), where \(\theta\) is in radians, has a sum to infinity.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 475, 920, 492]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 75, 106, 94]]<|/det|>
<label>10</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 75, 146, 94]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 75, 920, 96]]<|/det|>
Solve the equation \(\sin \alpha \cos \mathrm{e} \mathrm{c}^{2} \alpha + \cos \alpha \sec^{2} \alpha = 0\) for \(-\pi < \alpha < \pi\), where \(\alpha\) is in radians. [4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 81, 144, 100]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 81, 178, 100]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 75, 524, 104]]<|/det|>
Show that \(\frac{\cos \theta}{1 - \sin \theta} + \frac{1 - \sin \theta}{\cos \theta} = 2 \sec \theta .\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 78, 920, 97]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 470, 180, 489]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 456, 787, 494]]<|/det|>
Hence solve the equation \(\frac{\cos 3\phi}{1 - \sin 3\phi} + \frac{1 - \sin 3\phi}{\cos 3\phi} = 4\) for \(0^\circ \leqslant \phi \leqslant 180^\circ .\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 465, 920, 484]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[333, 868, 665, 889]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 87, 102, 106]]<|/det|>
<label>11</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 77, 885, 109]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 120, 322, 137]]<|/det|>
